timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: This OJEU contract notice is giving notice of the procurement of a public contract with a linked framework agreement attached as an additional but secondary component. The Contracting Authority is seeking to procure on behalf of itself and the Royal Borough of Kensington & Chelsea and the City of Westminster (both referred to as “the participating authorities”) an innovative private sector partner to invest in, develop and provide a range of total facilities management services through a strategic partnering arrangement (the "total FM Contract”) and a separate framework agreement. The Contracting Authority currently envisages that at the end of the procurement process the total FM contract and any framework agreement would be awarded to the successful supplier in its own right. However, the Contracting Authority is interested in exploring with the suppliers that are invited to participate in competitive dialogue what benefits, if any, would be realized by the Contracting Authority on behalf of itself or together with one or more of the participating authorities procuring as part of this procurement a strategic private sector partner with which to form a joint venture company and to which the total FM contract and any framework agreement would be awarded. The Contracting Authority therefore reserves the right as part of the current procurement to procure alongside the delivery of the total FM contract and any framework agreement, a partner with which to form a joint venture company or not to pursue this route further at the Contracting Authority’s discretion. The Contracting Authority and the participating authorities shall consider during the procurement process the structure of the client entity that it is anticipated will enter into the total FM contract and any framework agreement with the supplier and are currently giving consideration to the following options: (1) The Contracting Authority and the Participating authorities establish a wholly owned non-trading company (such as a Teckal company) which may in time convert into a trading company; or (2) The Contracting Authority enters into the total FM contract and any framework agreement on behalf of itself and the participating authorities; or (3) The Contracting Authority and the participating authorities enter into the total FM contract and any framework agreement. The above list is not an exhaustive list of options and the Contracting Authority reserves the right to consider alternative options and not to proceed with any of the options stated above. The principal outputs of the total FM contract will be to: — Deliver to specified performance levels, — Achieve efficiencies, — Deriving the benefits of a shared service model for the users of council services, — Provide value for money and accountable services from a customer perspective, — Reduce revenue costs in supporting the delivery of front-line services wherever possible, — Deliver continuous improvement and innovation in respect of these services. It is anticipated that the core requirements that may be included in the total FM contract will comprise the following: Hard Facilities Management including reactive repairs; maintenance; minor capital works; mechanical & electrical maintenance; re-lamping; fire detection and fighting systems; lifts, hoists and conveying systems; security, access and intruder systems; safety film; standby power systems maintenance; audio-visual equipment maintenance; television cabling; hard landscaping maintenance; soft landscaping maintenance; ponds and water features; internal planting; cut flowers; control of asbestos; water hygiene; statutory inspections; portable appliance testing; Building Management Systems (BMS); locksmith services; clocks; furniture management; signage. Soft facilities management services including catering; room bookings and community lettings; display boards; routine, periodic and reactive cleaning; cleaning of external areas; window cleaning; cleaning of exterior building fabric; graffiti and stain removal; sanitary consumables; linen and laundry; pest control; waste management; reception services; security services; mail services; messenger service; porterage; stationery supply; journal, magazine and newspaper supply; reprographics service. Managed services including health and safety management; authorized persons and permits to work; special needs services; risk management; environmental management; business continuity planning. Helpdesk and Computer Aided Facilities Management (CAFM) including helpdesk and CAFM; room bookings and lettings management; car park booking. Management and administration including performance monitoring; key performance indicators; contract management; quality approach; management of sub-contractors; Electronic Property Information Mapping System (ePIMS). The intention of the Contracting Authority and the participating authorities is that property management IT services such as maintaining the asset register, commercial lettings and project management are in scope for this procurement but the Contracting Authority and the participating authorities may review this during the procurement and decide not to proceed with the procurement of these services. This list is not exhaustive and consideration may be given both during the procurement process and the contract term to the inclusion of additional services or options for additional services which will assist in delivering the services and principal outputs listed above. The Contracting Authority intends to make the services delivered under the total FM contract available to schools maintained by the Contracting Authority and the participating authorities although the said schools shall not be under any obligation to use the total FM contract. The Contracting Authority wishes to enable other local authorities in addition to the participating authorities to benefit from this procurement. As such, in addition to the total FM contract the Contracting Authority is seeking to procure a separate framework agreement for call-offs by all local authorities and schools (maintained through public funds) in Greater London (the "participating bodies"). A list of the participating districts can be found at http://www.london.gov.uk/who-runs-london/london-boroughs/list-boroughs. The Contracting Authority is acting as a central purchasing body through which the participating bodies and schools (maintained through public funds) may wish to procure substantially similar services to those included in the total FM contract under a separate framework agreement but without any obligation on the participating bodies and the said schools to participate. Accordingly it is the intention that the participating bodies and the said schools should be able to rely on this procurement to purchase such services without the need for any further procurement process. The duration of an individual call-off contract under any framework agreement will not necessarily be limited to four years but will be governed by the subject matter of the call-off contract concerned. The form of the call-off contract will be agreed during the current procurement process subject to the right to make specific amendments in respect of an individual call-off. It is anticipated that services delivered under the total FM contract will commence in May 2013. The Contracting Authority envisages entering into any framework agreement at the same time as the total FM contract although the timing of any call-offs under the framework agreement will be a matter to be decided between the relevant participating body and the supplier. No guarantee or warranty is given as to the nature or volume, if any, of the services or the number of call-offs, if any, under any framework agreement. It should also be noted that in addition to any change in the structure of the client role as referred to in paragraphs 3 to 5 above, in the event of re-structuring within local government this procurement and / or the total FM contract and any framework agreement awarded will pass to successor authorities to the Contracting Authority, the participating authorities and the participating bodies as relevant and appropriate. The Contracting Authority reserves the right to award only the total FM contract and not to award any framework agreement or alternatively for the total FM contract and any framework agreement to commence on different dates.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Context. In 2008, The Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland Health Community (hereafter known as the “LLR”) formally agreed to transform healthcare in order to benefit the quality of life of the population served whilst delivering significant cost improvement. Spend on assets and estate infrastructure is one of the top three areas of expenditure for the LLR. Accordingly it is a priority area for efficiency improvement and transformation. LLR currently provides services across a geographical area of 1 000 square miles. The LLR currently has a multiplicity of delivery models with over 800 directly employed staff delivering its in-house FM services and a similar number of contracted staff employed by the external FM suppliers. The current property portfolio is extensive and identifies more than 850 discrete facilities (including NHS owned, leased and 3rd party property). NHS owned or leased property currently covers a space footprint of circa 496 000 m2. A recent space occupancy review identified an overall level of occupancy of less than 60 %. Options for significant space reduction are currently under development. Flexibility in solution design to meet strategic fit will therefore be critical to success. We are also seeking a partner who can help transform the use of the redesigned estate in support of our clinical strategy. In this context the University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust (“The Host Trust”) together with a minimum of two organisations within the East Midlands region have agreed to move to an ‘all shared’ model of delivery and management for FM. The solution will be procured and performance managed by UHL on behalf of the Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland Facilities Management Collaborative hereafter known as the “LLRFMC”. The LLRFMC is ambitious and is seeking an equally ambitious single operator to provide a transformational facilities management service solution to the sites and scope identified. Vision for the LLRFMC. A strategic partnership to deliver a high quality and sustainable Facilities Management service and transform the healthcare environment. Illustrative outputs. — In delivering the vision the outputs required from the operator include but are not be limited to: —— the effective and efficient delivery of FM services across partner organisations, —— year on year cost improvement without detriment to service quality, —— demonstrable customer focus, —— delivery of continuous quality and performance improvement through innovation, —— full Compliance with all standards and specifications, —— ability to adapt to the changing landscape, respond to local/national agendas and the differing needs of partners, —— opportunities to enhance and develop workforce capacity and capability and lead cultural change across partner organisations, —— creation of Investment and Commercial opportunities – with due consideration of accountability, governance & transparency. Technical information of the procurement. — The University Hospitals of Leicester (NHS Trust) ("UHL") wishes to procure a framework agreement for a term of four years for a full Facilities Management Service for the entire UHL owned estate (and other sites as described in Section II.1.2) with a single outsourced service provider, — UHL is procuring the framework agreement for itself and on behalf of the Participating Bodies as set out in Section VI.3, — The services that are being procured are split into Lot 1 and Lot 2 (see section VI.3 for more details), — UHL will only award a single framework agreement (to one service provider) and reserves the right to: —— not award the framework agreement at all, or —— to award part or all of the Lot 1 services, and —— to award part or all of the Lot 2 services under the single framework agreement award, — bidders must submit bids for both Lot 1 and Lot 2. Bids for Lot 1 only will not be accepted or evaluated and bids for Lot 2 only will not be accepted or evaluated. Any variant bids must still contain bids for Lot 1 and Lot 2, — lot 2 (part or all) will not be awarded without part or all of Lot 1 being awarded, — any bidder that passes the Lot 1 criteria minimum threshold as set out in the UHL evaluation criteria (to be set out in the Invitation to Submit Outline Solutions) shall have evaluated their Lot 2 submission in accordance with the criteria set out for this Lot, — UHL shall award the framework agreement (for part or all of the Lot 1and part or all of Lot 2 services) to the single bidder which has submitted the most economically advantageous bid for both Lot 1 and Lot 2 combined, taking into account the following steps in the evaluation process: (i) Any bidder will have to pass the minimum threshold for Lot 1; (ii) Provided that the bidder has passed this threshold, a preliminary score will be attributed to the submission in relation to Lot 1, in accordance with the evaluation criteria/weightings set out for this Lot; (iii) UHL will then attribute a preliminary score to the submission in relation to Lot 2, again in accordance with the evaluation criteria/weightings set out for this Lot; (iv) UHL will then identify the winning bidder for Lot 1 and 2 combined, in accordance with UHL's weighting formula applicable to a combination of the Lot 1 and Lot 2 preliminary scores to determine the most economically advantageous tender for the aggregate Lot 1 and Lot 2 service. — The services that are awarded by UHL under the Framework Agreement shall be available for call-off from the Framework Agreement by the Participating Bodies, —  The Framework Agreement is to be awarded without any obligation on UHL or the Participating Bodies to purchase services by way of calling-off contracts, — UHL requires the framework agreement to allow for the call-off of FM related services (in a variety of combinations of part or all of the Lot 1 and/or Lot 2 services) including but not limited to the following services: —— estates - engineering, —— building (including capital planning), —— grounds & gardens, —— catering - patient - retail, —— domestic services, —— portering services, —— postal services, —— reception services, —— security services, —— linen services, —— waste disposal services, —— car parking services, —— print & reprographic services, —— help desk, —— pest control, —— utilities management, —— switchboard, —— construction related services, —— business and management consultancy. — Participating Bodies shall be entitled to call-off contracts directly from the framework agreement subject to the terms of the framework agreement as awarded, — the duration of an individual call-off contract under any framework agreement shall not necessarily be limited to four years but will be governed by the subject matter of the call-off contract concerned. UHL intends the duration of call-off contracts to be for 1 to 7 years, — the form/s of the call-off contract/s shall be agreed during the procurement process for Lot 1 and are required to be sufficiently flexible to accommodate: —— specific amendments in respect of individual call-off contracts (for example to reflect the scope of service (acute or non-acute healthcare sites), and —— the restructuring of the health economy during the four year term of the framework agreement, — all bid costs shall remain the bidders' liability. UHL shall not be liable for any of the bidders' bid costs, — further descriptive information to be included in the memorandum of information.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Circle Housing Group ("Circle") comprises nine regional partners: Circle 33 Housing Trust, Russet Homes Limited, Mercian Housing Association, Merton Priory Homes, Mole Valley Housing Association, Wherry Housing Association, South Anglia Housing, Old Ford Housing Association and Roddons Housing Association, and three commercial subsidiaries: Circle Support, Circle Living and Invicta. Circle is commencing this procurement as part of its overall Business Transformation programme, a key part of which is how it seeks to procure its repairs and maintenance works. Therefore, on behalf of itself and its members (whether existing or future) Circle wishes to procure between two (2) and five (5) Providers to provide planned and responsive maintenance works and services across six (6) lots. The scope of those works includes but is not limited to: Responsive: works to the Circle Group housing and commercial stock including responsive repairs and maintenance works, minor voids, aids & adaptations, pest control, security board ups, fencing & pathways, snow clearance and gritting. Planned & Cyclical: works to the Circle Group housing and commercial stock including kitchen replacements, bathroom replacement, internal and external redecoration, heating installations, electrical upgrades, heating repairs, gas servicing (domestic & commercial), communal redecorations, window replacements, door replacements, roof renewals, external repairs, door entry installations, insulation works, insurance-related works, PAT testing, playgrounds repairs and maintenance, major voids works, estate cleaning, guttering and pipework repairs and maintenance, concrete repairs, vent fans repairs and maintenance, lift upgrades, door entry systems repairs and maintenance, lightning conductors repairs and maintenance, digital aerials repairs and maintenance, communal TV systems repairs and maintenance, CCTV repairs, maintenance and installation, work associated with solar power generation, utility saving activities, general green technology, grounds maintenance and water pumps repairs and maintenance, asbestos surveys and associated works. For the purposes of this procurement, Circle has divided the works into the following six lots: — Lot 1 – Responsive works in the Eastern Region (dormant), — Lot 2 – Responsive works in the Central and West Midlands regions, — Lot 3 – Responsive work in the Southern region, — Lot 4 – Planned & Cyclical works in the Eastern region, — Lot 5 – Planned & Cyclical works in the Central and West Midlands regions, — Lot 6 – Planned & Cyclical works in the Southern region. The detail of those regions and the current members of Circle within each will be set out in the Pre-qualification questionnaire referred to at section III.2.1 of this notice. In addition to lot 1, applicants can apply to undertake a maximum of three (3) lots but cannot undertake more than two (2) lots in the same discipline (eg responsive maintenance or planned and cyclical maintenance (excluding lot 1)). Applicants should note that this procurement is being conducted for the benefit of all members of Circle. A list of current members of the group is available at http://www.circle.org.uk. Applicants should note that this procurement is also undertaken for and on behalf of all future members of the Circle Group, as notified to the selected Providers via the relevant contractual process.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Wandsworth Council is inviting applications from suitably qualified main contractors who can demonstrate extensive experience in the management of complex, multi-trade social housing regeneration projects to express an interest in being considered to tender for a contract comprising the regeneration of two housing blocks on the York Road 1 Estate as part of a phased regeneration across the estate. Wandsworth Council is rated an “excellent” authority and has an outstanding track record on delivering estate regeneration projects. The. Council is seeking to appoint a single main contractor to carry out these works following extensive consultation with the estate residents. The project will be a separate contract, although the rest of the estate will be regenerated in its entirety over subsequent phases. The appointed main contractor will be required to demonstrate extensive experience in estate regeneration and major housing renewal schemes. The underlying principle for the project is to refurbish the elemental parts of the blocks to maintain/achieve the Decent Homes Standard in relation to the exterior elements / communal areas of the blocks, to adapt and alter the adjoining land and parking provision in accordance with modern standards and expectations and to introduce new, energy efficient low carbon technologies. The scheme will improve the physical condition and social perception of the estate, correcting defects / shortcomings with buildings of this type with respect to energy usage / conservation. The project will include the use of new technologies & energy efficient / low carbon / energy generating installations. The anticipated minimum works to be included within the scheme are as follows: Cyclical maintenance, including the full external repair and external redecoration of all previously painted masonry, metal, plastic and timber surfaces to all the blocks including communal areas, entrances, stairways, estate fencing etc, using high performance low maintenance paint systems; Works to the existing blocks may additionally encompass replacing / overlaying the existing cladding, roof covering and fenestration (window renewal) so as to increase their thermal and acoustic performance as well as their aesthetic appearance and thereby reduce future maintenance liabilities; Full upgrade of the existing controlled door entry and closed circuit television systems; The rewiring of individual tenanted properties and the renewal of switch-gear and lateral mains distribution boards; The removal and replacement of the existing communal area flooring including for any “structural detailing”; The installation of power generation technologies such as photo-voltaic cells and / or wind turbines and the necessary systems in order for the new energy generating plant to run the communal lighting, lifts and / or entry-call system; The installation of low energy communal area and estate lighting; The existing layout of estate blocks, roads, footpaths and car parking may be redesigned to achieve both more efficient use of land, improve the neighbourhood with regard to the designing out of anti-social behaviour and creation of a stronger feeling of community ownership. The works will be carried out whist the buildings are fully occupied by residents and will involve extensive resident liaison and consultation. Organisations will need to be adept in the management of specialist sub contractors and be able to demonstrate previous success in achieving high standards of quality with regard to similar works they have carried out.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The works under this contract is to include for the servicing, repair and maintenance of the existing security installations within the Bath and North East Somerset area of operations. The security installations that are required to be serviced include fire alarm and intruder alarm installations together with a number of access control installations. The location of the installations required to be serviced under this contract can be found elsewhere within this PQQ document. The key components of the term service contract are to provide the contractual basis for the following: 1. Maintenance & servicing – the implementation of a planned maintenance regime together with the regular and systematic servicing of all installations; 2. Testing & inspections – the regular testing and inspection of all installations; 3. Emergency call out – the provision of an emergency call out procedure with a maximum response time of two hours; 4. Breakdown and repair works – the carrying out of all necessary breakdown and repair works; 5. Alarm monitoring services – the provision of a 24 hour alarm monitoring service via a centralised alarm monitoring station; 6. Installation of new alarm signalling/communication equipment (Dualcom).

Blade test 2 is a 15.5 million GBP facility for testing wind turbine blades up to 100 m in length. Nautilus is a 14 5 million GBP facility for testing marine turbines.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The core requirement of this framework agreement will be to maintain, service, upgrade and repair all security equipment, systems and safety electronic muster systems, including access control equipment, fixed security cameras and all fence gating. This requirement supports a mandate of Nuclear Industry Security Regulations 2003 (NISR) for maintaining compliance in levels of security on nuclear licensed sites with an approved security plan. This security system maintenance service will ensure that each site remains compliant with NISR 2003, site licence conditions, approved site security plans, local, national and statutory instruments and obligations for operational requirements. Additional services covered by this framework agreement will include the monitoring and reporting on the performance of systems and recommendations for changes or improvements, including advice on all aspects of system redundancy and management.
UK-Leiston: repair and maintenance services of security equipment

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The Youth Justice Board supported by the Ministry of Justice Procurement Directorate intends to procure (but not limited to) Secure Escort Services for young people sentenced to custody and placed in a Secure Training Centre (STC) or a Secure Childrens Home (SCH). The escort provider will be expected to manage the transport of sentenced young people aged 12 to 16 years old across England and Wales. In 2010/11, the escort services involved c. 2 590 young people journeys covering over 185 000 miles, between approximately 350 locations. The escort service involves the transfer from courts to a STC or a SCH, from STC or SCH to courts, transfers between STCs, SCHs and Young Offender Institutions (YOI), hospital bedwatches and ad hoc escorts. The Youth Justice Board also wishes to explore, through a process of competitive dialogue, the potential efficiencies and benefits that might be gained from the secure escort of young people remanded to STCs or SCHs and the care and management of young people in the court cell area. The movement of 15 to 17 year olds from courts to YOIs or vice versa will continue to be managed by the National Offender Management Service (NOMS) under the responsibilty of the Prisoner Escort and Custody Services (PECS) contracts and is therefore outside the scope of this requirement.
UK-London: prisoner-escort services

The provision of a complete enterprise wide, end to end solution requiring the delivery of very large scale, complex projects encompassing all of the equipment, goods and services provided under lots 2 to 10. This Lot requires that the service provider can provide the goods, equipment and services from any or all of the lots under this Traffic Management Technology Framework: — Lot 2 - Traffic Signals and Ramp Metering, — Lot 3 - Electronic and Interactive Signs, — Lot 4 - Traffic and Vehicle Monitoring Services, — Lot 5 - Parking and Access Control Services, — Lot 6 - Environmental Monitoring Services, — Lot 7 - National Traffic Control (NTC), Urban Traffic Control (UTC) and Common Database Systems, — Lot 8 - Traffic Management Research and Consultancy, — Lot 9 - Street Lighting Services; and — Lot 10 - Traffic Safety.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Buying Solutions (the "Contracting Authority") is putting in place a Pan Government Collaborative Framework Agreement for use by Public Sector Bodies (as identified at Section VI.3) and any future successors to these organisations. Users of the Framework Agreement will include but not be limited to the Highways Agency and Local Authorities (both as identified at Section VI.3). The term "Traffic Management Technology" means the provision by the service provider of: (a) goods, equipment and services that address the specific sector needs of Public Sector Bodies, as further defined by all the Lots definitions in Section II.1.8; (b) outsourcing services for the goods, equipment and services defined in (a); and (c) outsourcing services for the legacy goods, equipment and services which are covered by the scope of each lot, as provided by the Public Sector Body or its third party contractors. Traffic Management Technology encompasses all forms of traffic (including vehicles, cycles, pedestrians, or similar forms of traffic) on or in proximity to any public space, areas permitting a public right of access or public highway (including motorways, roads, tracks, paths or similar forms of public access). Buying Solutions requires Traffic Management Technology solutions which will meet the commercial and technical requirements of small, medium and large Public Sector Bodies across the whole of the UK. The Framework Agreement will be let for 4 years. Suppliers may bid for one, more than one, or for all Lots; and must have a comprehensive solution capability specific to each of the Lots against which they wish to tender. Buying Solutions reserves the right for an electronic auction to be held by Public Sector Bodies during further competition among the parties to the Framework Agreement(s).
UK-Norwich: radio, television, communication, telecommunication and related equipment

cpvcode: Surveillance and security systems and devices
txtmark: Lewisham and Bromley Council each own a CCTV control room for the management and operation of their public safety CCTV and related systems. The Councils’ CCTV divisions are key strategic assets and community safety partners in dealing with crime and the fear of crime within the boroughs. A contractor(s) is required to supply a fully managed service including supervision and trained and SIA licensed CCTV operators to operate and manage the 24-hour CCTV control rooms at Eros House, Catford and Bromley Civic Centre. The contractor is expected to have a proven track record in CCTV control room management or duties of a similar nature and will be the single point of contact for all CCTV and related services within the scope of this contract. The contractor is to be responsible for the day to day running of the individual CCTV control rooms, including compliance with all relevant legislation, client liaison, housekeeping, management of data, fault reporting on the whole system and dealing with some technical issues relating to the use of the system. The Lewisham Council CCTV control room is responsible for the council’s community safety CCTV systems that includes fixed "town centre" PTZ cameras, safer stations systems and a re-locatable camera scheme, all of which are operated and recorded 24 hours / day. At present there are about 160 cameras in total but there are plans to expend through the integration of a separate CCTV control room that is responsible for the systems installed on the council’s housing estates. The Bromley Council CCTV control room is responsible for approximately 165 cameras that, again, includes fixed town centre and re-locatable cameras operated and recorded 24 hours / day. The services will include but not be limited to: — operation and management of the CCTV camera control and recording systems, — identifying and reporting incidents to the police and other agencies, — liaison with partner agencies including use of the Metropolitan Police radios, — preparation on video evidence for enforcement agencies and other requests for video images and information, — operation of the town centre radio systems, — identifying and reporting equipment faults to the council’s contractors and service suppliers — control of "out of hours" access to the building, — response to alarms, and — technical advice. The successful contractor must have its own 24-hour control centre to manage and support its staff in the delivery of this contract.

cpvcode: Surveillance and security systems and devices
timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Surveillance services. Surveillance and security systems and devices. The London Borough of Bromley and the London Borough of Lewisham (The Authorities) are looking to procure a service provider capable of delivering the activities identified within this notice jointly to each authority. While each Council will make its own contracting decisions (and reserves the right to place any of the contracts identified separately), both are looking to secure a joint arrangement in the placement of the specified service, providing it secures value for money (in terms of the criteria to be set out in the contract documentation) for each authority. The contract will be divided into 2 lots; Lot 1: CCTV control room management and operational services lot 2: maintenance of CCTV equipment bidders may submit tenders for either one or both Lots. The Authorities reserve the right to appoint a separate contractor for each Lot, or a single contractor for both lots.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The Scottish Crime Campus is a major construction project that will house the Scottish Crime and Drug Enforcement Agency, Scottish Police Services Authority Forensic Service (Glasgow), Crown Office Procurator Fiscal Service, HM Revenue & Customs and the Serious Organised Crime Agency in one location. The strategic aim of the project is to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of partner organisations in combating crime and supporting other organisations to do so. Key project aims focus on building a new facility that will enable the stakeholder agencies to maximise their combined operational effectiveness and efficiency and which demonstrates value for money in terms of quality, cost and time. The Project will aim to meet Sustainability and Environmental policy together with addressing any required Security Aspects. The construction of the facility has been split into 3 stages, This requirement relates to the Fit-out. Scottish Ministers are seeking to appoint a Management Contractor to manage the procurement and delivery of the work packages required for the Fit-out of the Scottish Crime Campus at Gartcosh, Lanarkshire. The number of work packages is estimated to be between 38-42. For the purposes of procuring the work packages, the Management Contractor will be required to use the Public Contracts Scotland portal, or any other suitable portal which can be accessed by Scottish Ministers. The Management Contractor will be required to work with a Scottish Ministers appointed Clerk of Works. Stage 3 of the Project may be subject to some strict Security Measures. The design for the project is currently at RIBA Stage F/G. The Management Contractor will also be required to support the Scottish Government’s economic and social regeneration objectives. Accordingly contract performance conditions may relate in particular to social and environmental considerations and consideration will be required of local economic objectives and the use of supported businesses. NOTE: To register your interest in this notice and obtain any additional information please visit the Public Contracts Scotland Web Site at http://www.publiccontractsscotland.gov.uk/Search/Search_Switch.aspx?ID=198736. The awarding authority has indicated that it will accept electronic responses to this notice via a 'Tender Submission Postbox' facility. Further details of this facility are available at http://www.publiccontractsscotland.gov.uk/PostBox/Postbox_Explain.aspx?ID=198736. Suppliers are advised to allow adequate time for uploading documents and to dispatch the electronic response well in advance of the closing time to avoid any last minute problems. The postbox closes precisely at the time stated.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Security services. The objective of this procurement exercise is to establish a framework for a single provider who can supply secure cash collection and cash in transit services to the West Midlands authorities. The service options shall therefore cover the secure collection, processing and consolidation and onward depositing of negotiable and non-negotiable money to high street banks, nominated cash receiving facilities, or other suitable receiving locations as specified. As part of the service, accurate records are required to be maintained, from which various reports and management information shall be presented. cash collections are likely to be requested from various premises or buildings of various types and designation, such as, but not limited to, cash offices, schools, leisure centres, public convinces, county parks and other local authority establishments. A potentially substantial requirement to the service will be cash collections made from the on-street and off-street car parks, including pay and display machines. In addition, it is also intended the framework shall offer the provision of a secure cash float service. Named authorities to use this arrangement are: Warwick, Redditch, Bromsgrove, Wyre Forest, Wychavon and Malvern Hills and Worcester City. However, this arrangement is open and available for all West Midlands authorities as listed on the IEWM Map - http://hub.westmidlandsiep.gov.uk/cncil.asp?PageRef=59.
UK-Leamington Spa: security services

Telecare and Telehealth products to meet the following Service User requirements: Raise alarm to summon assistance - must enable communication with a monitoring facility either on location or offsite. Door entry security including voice, video communication and bogus caller alarm. Fire and smoke safety systems. Environmental controls and hazard detectors for example but not limited to: carbon monoxide, natural gas, lighting, temperature. Personal monitors and sensors of health conditions for example but not limited to: epilepsy, enuresis. fall sensors, pressure pads. Location monitors for example but not limited to: door and property exist sensors, home activity, personal location monitors, pagers. Vital Signs monitoring for example but not limited to: Blood pressure, BMI, coagulation, cardiac arrhythmia, temperature, medication reminder, weighing scales. Hosting and communication devices to enable effective functionality, interoperability, data transmitting and recording of the above as well as telecommunication with a monitoring centre. Equipment to establish and maintain a call monitoring centre service.

The Northern Housing Consortium (NHC) are a not for distributed profit, Membership Organisation providing representation, information and services to improve efficiencies to its UK wide member base. The NHC intend to establish a framework agreement to deliver Assisted Living Technology systems to all current and future Members of the Northern Housing Consortium. It is envisaged that Contracting Organisations will be drawn from: Housing Registered Providers, Local Authorities, Strategic Health Authorities, Primary Care Trusts, Adult Social Care, General Practicioner practices and consortia, NHS Confederation, private property mangement companies and any other organisation wishing to purchase Assisted Living systems with the option to have them installed and maintained within managed accomodation or a private dwelling. To include the option of a call centre monitoring facility to offer a range of services inlcuding but not restricted to: alarm telecommunication handling, trend monitoring, emergency response, mobile response, health diagnostic and triage services. Members of the Consortium are national acros England and Wales. A list of current Members will be provide in the tender documentation. Supplier appointed to the Framework Agreement will be updated on membership as and when Member join or leave the Consortium. Tenderers will be asked to state a preference for geographical areas.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: To provide sufficient numbers of trained stewards and security personnel on a "guaranteed availability", call-off basis for an outdoor, national event in central Edinburgh, Scotland. The required availability is needed across the full contract term of 3 years. This is a large city-wide event involving members of the Royal Family, invited guests and members of the public. The event will require a significant number of security staff to be deployed at very short notice and in close coordination with the Lothian Police and the event organisers. The contract requires the provision and organisation, transportation and deployment of all security staff, including the provision of high-visibility clothing and communications media (radio sets). In addition the provision of 4 walk through scanners will be required. There will be no specific provision made for contractors’ storage or accommodation and so bidders should make these arrangements for themselves. All costs associated with the deployment of the staff will be the responsibility of the participating contractor. Plans of the required mobilisation points around Edinburgh city centre will be issued to all participating tenderers at the full tender stage. The successful contractor will be required to assign a contact person who has authority to make decisions on behalf of their organisation and to attend occasional planning and progress meetings with the Contracting Authority in Edinburgh throughout the contract term.
UK-Edinburgh: guard services

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The contract is for the provision for a static manned guarding service at NHS Blood and Transplant for Manchester and Liverpool blood centres. NHSBT would also reserve the right, during the term of the contract, to extend the service to additional sites by agreement with the contractor. The contractor shall be responsible for providing a vigilant, visible, and active presence that shall deter criminal activity in NHSBT providing reassurance to legitimate users of those premises. The Contractor shall achieve this through routine proactive surveillance of the sites, including external grounds, car park areas and by responding to requests for assistance from NHSBT staff and visitors. The contractor shall also make provision for a regional mobile key holding service to all main and satellite sites within the Northern region. NHSBT would also reserve the right, during the term of the contract, to extend the key holding service to additional sites across the UK by agreement with the contractor.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Derby City Supporting People are tendering the service for Home improvement agency which provides help to older home owners aged 60+ enabling them to stay safely and independently in their homes. The aim of the service is to help vulnerable older home owners aged 60+ stay safely and independently in their own homes by providing minor works service in line with its Renewal Policy and by providing a handy van scheme to carry out small repair and maintenance tasks for older people living in their own homes. Client-centred support provided in a person’s own home will be combined with expertise in making changes to the physical fabric of the home. The service will provide a holistic review of service user needs and will enable appropriate signposting and referral to other community services that may need to be accessed to enable service users to maintain their independence, health and well-being in their chosen home for the foreseeable future.
UK-Derby: residential homes construction work

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: To provide the following provision and services to Plymouth Community Homes and its residents across the city of Plymouth, Devon, UK: The contract will comprise of a 24 hour 365 day alarm monitoring service for older people, people with disabilities and victims of domestic violence/hate crime, plus lone worker monitoring for support staff. The successful contractor will need the capacity to monitor various alarm systems, including hardwired pull-cord systems, dispersed alarm units and variety of telecare sensors including, smoke, CO2, flood, bogus caller and fall detectors. The service will need to be delivered in accordance with the TSA Code of Practice Part 1, and potential contractors will need to evidence accreditation and ongoing compliance to the code. The contract will be for a period of 3 years with the option to extend for a further 1 year.
UK-Plymouth: alarm-monitoring services

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The contracting authorities are seeking an innovative private sector partner or partners to participate in a new Public Private Partnership vehicle (a "Local Education Partnership" or "LEP") to be established jointly with some or all of the contracting authorities. The LEP will provide (or arrange for the provision of) "Partnering Services", which will include (but not be limited to) the development of a strategic investment programme for: (a) educational facilities; (b) shared and/or co-located education and community use facilities, including sports, leisure, library, health and social care facilities; (c) any other facilities to be provided by one or more of the contracting authorities (where contracting authorities are local authorities) in the exercise of the powers contained in Section 2(1) of the Local Government Act 2000 (together the "Relevant Facilities") in the contracting authorities' area. These Partnering Services will also comprise the following services: (a) strategy advisory services; (b) programme management services; (c) project development services; (d) procurement consultancy services; and (e) procurement and delivery or management of all services required to deliver the strategic investment programme for the Relevant Facilities (including through the provision, integration and management of supply chain arrangements). It is anticipated that such services may include: (i) architectural services; (ii) engineering services; (iii) construction services; (iv) technical services; (v) building services; (vi) hard facilities management services; (vii) soft facilities management services; (viii) information communication and technology ("ICT") services; (ix) educational support services; (x) education programme development services; (xi) educational strategy services, For a period of up to 15 years; The Relevant Facilities, which may be a mixture of new build and refurbished facilities, will be delivered under the Private Finance Initiative (PFI) and/or design and build arrangements. This may include the delivery of the Relevant Facilities through separate SPVs established by the LEP. Where an SPV is established, the shareholders in such SPV may include the LEP, third party equity providers and supply chain members. The contracting authorities may contract directly with the LEP or, where an SPV is established, with the SPV. The LEP may also be required to provide for, or arrange for the provision (through supply chain arrangements) of, the management and/or integration of the Partnering Services, design and build and construction contracts, facilities management services, support services and ICT services (this list is not exhaustive) at facilities other than the Relevant Facilities, including, for example, the provision of ICT services at the authorities' libraries and youth centres, the provision of countywide education and corporate Wide Area Network (WAN) facilities and the provision of central ICT support services, where the authorities' existing arrangements are either transferred or expire. Further details are contained in the Descriptive Document and Pre Qualification Questionnaire (PQQ) (see Section VI.3 for details of how to obtain these).
UK-Ipswich: business and management consultancy and related services

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The contracting authorities are seeking an innovative private sector partner or partners to participate and invest in a new public private partnership vehicle (a "local education partnership" or "LEP") to be established jointly with some or all the contracting authorities. The LEP will provide (or arrange for the provisions of) "partnering services", which will include (but not limited to) the development of a strategic investment programme for: (a) secondary educational facilities; and (b) potentially primary, sixth form, further education and other learning and educational facilities; (c) potentially community services and neighbourhood facilities (which may include leisure sports and / or office facilities); (d) potentially other children’s services facilities; (e) potentially social care facilities; (f) potentially office and other accommodation or facilities (together the "relevant facilities") in the contracting authorities' area. It should be noted that (b) to (f) do not fall within the LEP’s exclusivity and may not in fact be required by the contracting authorities from the LEP. These partnering services will also comprise of the following services: (a) strategy advisory services; (b) programme management services; (c) project development services; (d) procurement consultancy services; and (e) procurement and delivery or management of all services required to deliver the strategic investment programme for the relevant facilities (including through the provision, integration and management of supply chain arrangements). It is anticipated that such services may include: (i) architectural services; (ii) engineering services; (iii) construction services; (iv) technical services; (v) building services; (vi) hard facilities management services; (vii) soft facilities management services; (viii) information communication and technology ("ICT") services; (ix) educational support services; (x) education programme development services; (xi) educational strategy services; and (xii) business and management consultancy and related services for a period of up to 15 years. The relevant facilities, which may be a mixture of new build and refurbished facilities, will be delivered under the private finance initiative (PFI) and/or design and build arrangements. This may include the delivery of the Relevant Facilities through separate SPVs established by the LEP. Where an SPV is established, the shareholders in such SPV may include the LEP, third party equity providers and supply chain members. The contracting authorities may contract directly with the LEP or where an SPV is established, with the SPV. The LEP may also be required to provide for, or arrange for the provision (through supply chain arrangements) of, the management and/or integration of the partnering services, design and build and construction contracts, facilities management services, support services and ICT services (this list is not exhaustive) where the authorities existing arrangements are either transferred or expire. Further details are contained in the descriptive document and pre qualification questionnaire (PQQ)(see section VI.3 for details of how to obtain these).
UK-Southampton: business and management consultancy and related services

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The NEC is looking for providers who can provide for the supply, installation and maintenance of a replacement security and traffic system. This will comprise of a number of scope items which may include. Replacement CCTV Cameras and Storage devices and additional systems that support a state of the art CCTV system. Enhancement of existing ANPR systems (This may involve replacement of current technologies used). Enhancement and development of current access control systems across the site (This may involve replacement of current technologies used). To provide analytic tools for both real time and offline recorded data. To introduce systems that allows integration of security traffic and management information systems. Car Parking Counting loops and systems to interrogate data from car parking loops. Mobile ANPR facility. To facilitate the power and civils relating to the works. Extension to current access control facilities within the NEC. To provide options for the infrastructure to facilitate the connections of the systems around site which may include both wired and wireless solutions. To provide automated and proactive technology for response to incidents which will include alerts alarms and automated control of some facilities from both the security and traffic system. Mobile and flexible CCTV system that can deployed on exhibitor stands. Suitable human interface devices for operators to utilise the technology delivered as part of the solution. To provide other appropriate technology that may be defined as part of a CCTV and traffic system. The scope of this project does not include car parking enforcement systems. Note: To register your interest in this notice and obtain any additional information please visit the myTenders Web Site at http://www.myTenders.org/Search/Search_Switch.aspx?ID=64533.
UK-Birmingham: repair and maintenance services of security and defence materials

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Cambridgeshire County Council requires an integrated and fully supported building access control system for its main shire hall site and regional offices. The specification represents current and future needs, and the contractor is required to maintain an access control system that shall include a simple and easy-to-use graphical user interface for configuration and administration. The future proofed, scaleable solution shall include local operational control of all access points. The access control system client and server software shall be used in conjunction with intelligent door controllers to provide a distributed access control and monitoring system. Electric conductors for access control systems. Access control system. Magnetic card readers. Command and control system. Electronic security lock. Security software package. Security equipment. Security services. Electronic security lock.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Larne Harbour Limited is seeking to appoint a security provider to provide security services at the Port of Larne in Northern Ireland and possibly also at the Ports of Troon and Cairnryan on the west coast of Scotland. It is anticipated that the scecurity provider will assume full management responsibility for the day-to-day operation of manned security services at the Port of Larne in accordance with all port-related security codes and regulations. The security provider shall follow in their entirety the regulations and procedures set out in security instructions prepared by the port facility security officer and as amended from time-to-time and all other relevant legislation, codes of practice and regulations. The security provider must be and remain a security industry authority approved contractor and must remain so throughout the duration of the contract. All security provider staff must hold and retain appropriate front line and non-front line licences. Front line staff will require a security guard or door supervisor licence. The total scope of the services will be finalised in conjunction with the chosen security provider but it is envisaged that it will include the following at the port of larne (a similar but smaller operation exists at Cairnryan with a seasonal operation in place at Troon). Summary of services to be provided under the contract. 1. Fleet street checkpoint (approximately 14 500 hrs per annum). a. Access control to and from the restricted area of the port. b. Searching of people, property and vehicles. 2. Southend checkpoint (approximately 14 000 hrs per annum). a. Access control to and from the restricted Area of the port. b. Searching of people, property and vehicles. 3. Vehicle search area (approximately 14 000 hrs per annum). a. Access control to and from the restricted area of the port. b. Searching of people, property and vehicles. 4. Foot passenger search area (approximately 8 500 hrs per annum). a. Access control to and from the restricted area of the port. b. Searching of people and property. 5. Mackean Quay (hours included in Southend checkpoint). a. Traffic control of vehicles leaving and entering the ship on the berth. b. Control of access into the ship. 6. Chaine Quay (approximately 1 700 hrs per annum – March to October only). a. Traffic control of vehicles leaving and entering the ship on the berth. b. Control of access into the ship. 7. Set Down Area (approx 1 300 hrs per annum – March to October only). a. Traffic control of traffic entering and exiting the area. b. Prevention of unattended parking. c. Control of the bus and taxi park. d. Assisting customers with special needs. 8. Foot patrols (provided by above staffing outside peak traffic movements). During contract hours and as duties and traffic permits, foot patrols of the port perimeter and car parks will be carried out by two security staff working together. 9. Any other duties. On occasions the contractor will provide security personnel for other duties as required by the arrival or departure of unscheduled ships or other special events. These duties will be charged at the hourly rate agreed for this contract.
UK-Larne: security services

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The contracting authorities are seeking an innovative private sector partner or partners to participate and invest in a new Public Private Partnership vehicle (a "Local Education Partnership" or "LEP") to be established jointly with some or all the contracting authorities (as noted in Section VI.3). Partnering Services - The LEP will provide or arrange for the provision of "Partnering Services", which may include (but shall not be limited to) the development of a strategic investment programme for some or all of the following: (a) educational facilities which will include secondary schools and may include primary schools, voluntary aided and foundations including trust schools and academies and other places of primary, secondary and tertiary education, potentially including the provision of residential accommodation for pupils at one or more of the schools; (b) other children's services facilities (including but not limited to children's centres, family centres, children's homes, sure start facilities, after school club facilities, youth clubs etc); (c) community facilities that support educational outcomes (such as but not limited to co-location and integration of key services such as education, social services, children's services etc); (d) accommodation for adult education and Special Education Needs education; (e) leisure facilities (including but not limited to swimming pools, sports facilities, theatres and studios etc) (f) community facilities whether co-located with any of the above facilities or freestanding (including but not limited to halls, drop-in centres, crèches, sheltered workshops etc) (g) social service facilities (including but not limited to day centres); (h) office and other accommodation for any of the contracting authorities; (i) facilities for library and other community services; (j) any other facilities to be provided by one or more of the contracting authorities whether in exercise of the powers contained in Section 2(1) of the Local Government Act 2000 (promotion of well being) or otherwise (together the "Relevant Facilities") in the contracting authorities' area. The Partnering Services may also comprise of the following services: (a) strategy advisory services; (b) programme management services; (c) project development services; (d) procurement consultancy services; and (e) procurement and delivery or management of all services required to deliver the strategic investment programme for the Relevant Facilities (including through the provision, integration and management of supply chain arrangements). It is anticipated that such services may include: (i) architectural services; (ii) engineering services; (iii) construction services; (iv) technical services; (v) building services; (vi) hard facilities management services; (vii) soft facilities management services; (viii) information communication and technology ("ICT") services; (ix) educational support services; (x) education programme development services; (xi) educational strategy services; and (xii) services supporting wider regeneration initiatives. The LEP will be required to provide Partnering Services for a period of up to 15 years. The Relevant Facilities, which may be a mixture of new build and refurbished facilities, will be delivered under the Private Finance Initiative (PFI) and/or design and build arrangements. This may include the delivery of the Relevant Facilities through separate special purpose vehicles ("SPV") established by the LEP or in the case of capital works or new projects to be provided on an existing PFI site, by the existing SPV for such site. Where an SPV is established, the shareholders in such SPV may include the LEP, third party equity providers and supply chain members. The contracting authorities may contract directly with the LEP or where an SPV is established, with the SPV. ICT - The contracting authorities will require the LEP to deliver or procure the delivery of an integrated ICT managed service for an initial period of 5 years with an option to extend the contract for a further 12 months. It is intended that there will be exclusivity in relation to the ICT managed service which will be in accordance with the Strategic Partnering Agreement. Existing Arrangements - The LEP may also be required to provide for, or arrange for the provision (through supply chain arrangements) of, the management and/or integration of the Partnering Services, design and build and construction contracts, facilities management services, support services and ICT services (this list is not exhaustive) where the contracting authorities' existing arrangements are either transferred or expire. Further details are contained in the Descriptive Document and pre-qualification questionnaire (PQQ) (see section VI.3 for details on how to obtain these).
UK-Worcester: business and management consultancy and related services

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: Stoke-on-Trent and Staffordshire Fire and Rescue Authority (the "Authority") wishes to contract for the design, build, finance, operation, management and maintenance of community fire stations and associated buildings and facilities across the Stoke-on-Trent and Staffordshire areas. It is intended that the scheme will comprise the building of ten new community fire stations. The Authority has also identified appropriate "reserve" stations, all of which have outline planning approval and can be substituted for the stations currently intended to be included within the scheme if irresolvable problems occur at any of those stations. It is anticipated that the scheme also includes the provision of training facilities at all of the sites. The Authority does, however, reserve the right to change the number and location of facilities within the scope of the project. The appointed contractor may be required to provide decant services on site where this is deemed necessary. The appointed contractor may also be required to provide temporary accomodation during any decant. The appointed contractor will be required to provide building and facility management, IT, security, janitorial, cleaning and grounds maintenance services to the facilities (the "Facilities Management Services") and other services. The Authority retains the right to change the scope of the Facilities Management Services. The appointed contractor may also be required to construct additional facilities and/or provide additional facilities management services at any of the sites including, without limitation, facilities to be used by other partner organisations. The current expectation is that the project will be procured by way of private finance through the UK Government's Private Finance Initiative. The Authority, however, reserves the right to provide or procure capital contributions and/or finance to the project from other sources, such as through the use of prudential borrowing, other capital contributions and/or loans from the HM Treasury's Infrastructure Finance Unit. The amount of any such capital contribution and/or funding will be determined by the Authority during the procurement. The Authority also reserves the right to involve European Investment Bank funding in the project.
UK-Stone: construction work for buildings relating to law and order or emergency services

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: The Dudley Grid for Learning (DGfL) is an educationally focused ICT service. Formed in 1999, DGfL has delivered a fully managed service to 110 schools in and around the Dudley Metropolitan Borough through a PFI contract. The current extended contract (DGfL2) will come to an end in January 2011 and subsequently the contracting authority is seeking an innovative private sector partner or partners to provide a new managed service for educational ICT in association with Dudley Grid for Learning 3 (DGfL3). It is proposed that DGfL3 be tailored in such a way that it will provide flexible, affordable options to all schools in the borough who wish to take the service, but also support the Primary and other capital build programmes and be procured in such a way that it would be capable of being an approach to the ICT managed service component of any future inclusion by Dudley MBC in and any participation by it in the BSF programme. Teaching, learning & e-leadership are key areas, the DGfL3 programme is envisaged to support the further development of these areas in schools and other learning locations. These areas are essential pre-requisites to foster innovation and to drive the step change in provision and outcomes required from DGfL3 to deliver the ICT component of Dudley's "Vision 2025". To achieve this, the ICT managed service provider is expected to assist and support DGfL3 in providing inspirational learning environments. Dudley MBC is not able to guarantee any particular level of participation from schools nor whether it will participate in or include the ICT managed service wholly or partially in any BSF programme; this will depend on the quality, flexibility and innovation of the offering provided by the successful bidder. The ICT Managed Service Provider will be expected to deliver their proposed service to strict KPI's based around measures including: service availability, educational impact and service usage. The ICT managed service provider is also required to provide and/or manage existing, inter alia, the following services as part of its service delivery: (a) Network infrastructure, hardware, educational and curriculum software titles, schools information management systems (IMS) including the support and training to use these systems, helpdesk, and network and technical support; (b) Programme management services for the full integration of ICT provision in new and refurbished buildings; (c) Project development services throughout the whole programme; (d) Assistance in the Development of Learning Technologies to champion Dudley's 'Vision 2025' in support of educational transformation; (e) The WAN and internet services may be included in the procurement and the MSP should explore the Dudley Corporate ICT Services potential for shared WAN services and internet. Dudley reserves the right to remove this element from the procurement process; (f) Ensure the affordability, availability and sustainability of the proposed ICT solutions, delivering value for money for the local authority and all users; (g) Confirm the technical feasibility of the proposed ICT solutions ensuring that these are sufficiently flexible to meet the needs of all users; (h) Propose, develop and operate a scheme enabling those learners who so wish to have access to affordable individual personal learning devices. Further details are contained in the pre qualification questionnaire (PQQ). CPV codes relate to: Computer-related services. Installation of telecommunications equipment. Installation services of computers and office equipment. Hardware installation services. Systems and technical consultancy services. Data collection and collation services. Computer network services. System quality assurance assessment and review services. Provision of services to the community. Software integration consultancy services. Hardware consultancy services. System and support services. Security services. Education and training services. Disaster recovery services. Data network management and support services. Hardware integration consultancy services. Help-desk and support services. Repair, maintenance and associated services related to personal computers, office equipment, telecommunications and audio-visual equipment. Software testing. Software-related services. Data services. Closed-circuit surveillance system. Software programming and consultancy services. Information technology services. Software package and information systems. Facilities management services for computer systems maintenance. Computer equipment and supplies. Software supply services. Software implementation services.
UK-Dudley: computer-related services

txtmark: Maidstone Borough Council wishes to invite suitably qualified and experienced contractors to tender for the upgrade of its control centre to digital technology and for the provision of CCTV Equipment and Maintenance for a period of up to 5 years. This procurement will be divided into lots to cover Control Centre Upgrade, Maintenance of the whole CCTV infrastructure and the supply and installation of CCTV equipment. Tenderers will be expected to submit a bid for all lots. Current Set-Up. Maidstone has an existing extensive CCTV network throughout the Borough currently comprising of 124 CCTV cameras in High Streets, Car Parks and other public domain locations. Images are controlled and recorded in a purpose built control centre at the Town Hall Maidstone using both analogue and digital technology. Surveillance and security systems and devices. Security equipment. Security cameras. Surveillance system.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s):
txtmark: Total Outsource Lot 1 for the Provision of comprehensive hard and soft facilities management services at the British Antarctic Survey (BAS) office in Cambridge. BAS is a component of the Natural Environment Research Council (NERC). Based in Cambridge, BAS is a world-class science organisation which has its focus on the Antarctic and Arctic regions, addressing key global and regional issues through research, survey and monitoring. It has, for over 60 years, undertaken the majority of Britain’s Scientific Research on and around the Antarctic continent. BAS has its main centre in Cambridge and comprises of office, laboratory, workshop and logistic facilities. BAS is looking for a FM contractor to undertake comprehensive hard and soft service provision to the Cambridge site only, comprising of: Building and asset maintenance (PPM) Reactive unplanned maintenance. The BAS Cambridge site is a complex facility with Laboratories, workshops, logistics, temperature control and IT facilities, Cleaning Services, Waste Services, Catering Services, Security Services, Porter/Post Services, Grounds Services, Emergency and Business continuity Service, Help Desk Service. Please see Lots 2 Hard FM and Lot 3 Soft FM below. Please note there will be an internal bid from BAS Building Services for the Hard FM. Catering services, Please note that we reserve the right to remove the Catering service from this requirement. However if this happens the successful contractor will be required to manage this service on behalf of BAS.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s)
txtmark: "The project is in 2 distinct phases: Phase 1 - Installation of a new central CCTV control room adjacent to the existing control room, this includes builders work moving walls & doors, new suspended ceiling, mechanical ventilation & air conditioning and electrical services to the room, operators desks and CCTV equipment including new video wall, dual operators control room positions and remote displays in 2 out lying buildings. The replacement of the existing analogue matrix and digital video recorders (DVR) with a IP based solution (which must be 100 % compatible with our existing Pelco Endura installation) including the integration of our existing camera network into the new system. Installation & servicing of 9 new street-scape cameras, including 4 pole mounted cameras. Replacement of 13 existing street-scope external cameras and associated ancillary equipment replacement of matrix and DVR in our Jordanhill Campus. Installation of CCTV signage. Training of key CCTV operational personnel and on site technical staff. Phase 2 - is the maintenance of the existing and new installed system. The maintenance contract is anticipated to run for an initial 1 year, Extended year on year up to 4 years dependant on contractor performance.". Note: To register your interest in this notice and obtain any additional information please visit the Public Contracts Scotland web site at http://www.publiccontractsscotland.gov.uk/Search/Search_Switch.aspx?ID=185331.
UK-Glasgow: closed-circuit surveillance system

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s):
txtmark: Thurrock Council, a Unitary Authority at the heart of the Thames Gateway, is inviting Tenders for the provision of a 24/7 Concierge Service at three high-rise blocks in Godman Road, Chadwell-St-Mary, Essex RM16. The concierge reception area is linked to the three blocks by fully enclosed walkways and entry to the blocks is controlled by an electronic fob-reading system. The service will include: (1)Assisting residents with basic information about Council services and providing directions in how to access them; (2)Providing information to the residents and their families about facilities in and around the blocks; (3)Screening and validation of all visitors to the blocks; (4) Patrolling all secure, internal and external communal areas; (5) The operation and monitoring of CCTV equipment; (6) Communicating with a diverse community, local management, other Council services and contractors; (7) Providing a transparent, diverse, accessible and value for money service;
UK-Grays: reception services

txtmark: To provide security guarding and general campus services to the University's 3 separate hall of residence sites. The duties broadly consist of security, portering (including light domestic duties) and reception duties. The primary aim of the residential security team is to provide a high level of customer service and protect University property, residents, visitors, staff and their property from any acts of a criminal nature. The secondary aim is to assist/support the Residential Services operation in providing portering and reception duties. As an example these duties include booking in students upon arrival (including associated administration), litter picking, dealing with fire alarm activations/evacuations, domestic duties, movement of equipment/stock on site.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s):
txtmark: There is a requirement for the provision of Static Guarding Services at the Edinburgh site of the British Geological Survey (BGS). The contractor has to provide guarding cover for the following times: — Monday-Friday 17:00-8:30, — Saturday-Sunday 24 hour cover. In addition to this, extra cover is required for Public Holidays, and Privilege days. The expected role of the guard when on site, will be to maintain a Reception and telephone service, which must be kept operational, as staff require 24 hour access to and from the building. In addition to the reception duties, the contract will be asked to monitor CCTV cameras, and also undertake regular internal patrols of the building. Applicants should be made aware that this contract may potentially be opened up for other local Research Council Sites to join. More details of the scope of services required will be sent to contractors that successfully reach the tendering stage.

timark: Short description of the contract or purchase(s):
txtmark: The College intends to enter into a Contract with an appropriately qulaified and experienced Contractor for the provision of high quality control room, manned guarding and security services to the College. Contractors will be expected to provide an on-site Manager who will: — develop and manage the Contract, — implement cost control including the operation of a "Banking of Hours" system, — provide communication and protective equipment, — establish a management structure and engage a team of suitably qualified: —— uniformed control room staff, —— uniformed staff group to cover specified core hours. — ensure observance of health, safgety and environmental policies, regulations and statutory requirements, — agree a quality policy and develop a quality control manual. The Contractor will provide all services to the specified Contract Service throughout the period of the contract in a professional, efficient, effective and safe way and shall provide services in a manner to promote and enhance the image and reputation of the Employer to the reasonable satisfaction of the Employer in undertaking: Control Room Services as follows: — 24 hour 7 day week service during term and non-term periods, — CCTV operation - two guard duty at key times, — mobile patrol to cover satellite sites, — manned emergency call answer and out-of-hours advice service, — alarm response. Manned Guarding Services through the employment of sufficient staff at all times to carry out duties which include, but not exclusively, the following: — operate CCTV as necessary to support Control Room staff, — site / Car Parking / Vehicles / Pedestrian access to the sites, — staff / Students / Visitors - ID checks, meeting, directing, escorting visitors, — cash - escort when required, — buildings - patrols, fire prevention, door controls, site clearance, meter checks and assitingb caretakers / cleaners, — patrols - non-aggressive face, sensitive, visible profile, — alarm response, — key holding responsibilities. The Contractoor will engage sufficient qulaified staff to give a high quality service to meet the flexible basic hours required. The Contractor will undertake staff vetting and screening including Enhanced CRB checks, and provide appropriate security training to meet the College's requirements, first aid training.
UK-Sheffield: security services

txtmark: This framework agreement (Ref: 12/10 PC/3) is for the provision of uniformed manned guarding, mobile patrol, CCTV monitoring, alarm response, keyholder services, technological solutions and event stewarding/marshalling services at various locations throughout Scotland including the Highlands and Islands within each authorities geographic boundary.
